abstract.t: The Web Real-Time Communication (WebRTC) working group is charged to provide protocols to support for direct interactive rich communication using audio, video, and data between two peers' web-browsers. This document specifies an actual (minor) protocol for how the JS-layer dataChannel objects provide the data channels between the peers.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The Data Channel Protocol is designed to provide, in the WebRTC context , a generic transport service allowing Web Browser to exchange generic data in a bidirectional peer to peer fashion. As discussed in the protocol uses Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) encapsulated on Datagram Transport Layer Security (DTLS) as described in to benefit from their already standardized transport and security features.

section.title: Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Terminology
section.t:
This document uses the following terms:
An SCTP association.
A unidirectional stream of an SCTP association. It is uniquely identified by a stream identifier.
A bidirectional channel consisting of two SCTP streams.

section.title: Opening Handshake
section.t: The opening handshake is based on the multimedia session description exchange that happens between the browsers, typically through a Web Server acting as the signaling service.
defines the protocol identifier, 'SCTP/DTLS', and defines how to establish an SCTP association over DTLS using the Session Description Protocol (SDP).
The SCTP association is created with the number of streams specified by the application, and if not specified, then it SHOULD default to 16 streams.
It is recommended that additional streams be available dynamically based on .

section.title: Control Messages
section.t: Data Channel Control Messages are sent to manage opening bidirectional channels. A DATA_CHANNEL_OPEN is sent on the Stream that is intended to be used to send in that direction, and a response (DATA_CHANNEL_OPEN_RESPONSE) using the same structure is sent back on the Stream to be used for the other direction, with a reverse_direction_stream entry holding the Stream number the DATA_CHANNEL_OPEN was sent on. This allows association of the Streams that define the bidirectional channel.
Errors are returned by setting the first 16 bits of the msg_type_data field to a non-0 value. In this case the original sender of DATA_CHANNEL_OPEN shall close the channel.

section.title: OPEN_REQEUEST Message
section.t: This message is sent initially on the stream used for user messages using the channel.

list.t: This field holds the IANA defined message type for the the OPEN_REQEUEST message. The suggested value of this field for IANA is 0x01.

This field specifies the type of the channel to be opened:
The channel provides a reliable bi-directional communication channel.

If this flag is set, the channel does not need to preserve the message sequencing.

This field is ignored if a reliable channel is used. If a partial reliable channel with limited number of retransmissions is used, this field specifies the number of retransmissions. If a partial reliable channel with limited lifetime is used, this field specifies the maximum life-time in milli seconds.

section.title: OPEN_RESPONSE Message
section.t: This message is sent in response to an OPEN_REQEUEST message on the stream used for user messages using the channel. In case of an error a different stream might be used.

list.t: This field holds the IANA defined message type for the the OPEN_RESPONSE message. The suggested value of this field for IANA is 0x02.
The identifier for the incoming stream of the channel. The corresponding OPEN_REQEUEST message was received on this stream.

section.title: OPEN_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT Message
section.t: This message is sent in response to an OPEN_RESPONSE message on the stream used for user messages using the channel.

list.t: This field holds the IANA defined message type for the the OPEN_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT message. The suggested value of this field for IANA is 0x03.

section.title: Adding a Channel
section.t: When one side wants to add a channel, it picks an unused outgoing stream, and if need be, negotiates an increase in the number of outgoing streams available. It then sends a OPEN_REQEUEST control message on the outgoing stream.

When an OPEN_REQEUEST is received on an incoming stream, an unused outgoing stream is picked, and if need be, negotiates an increase in the number of outgoing streams available. A OPEN_RESPONSE message is sent on the outgoing stream, with the Reverse Stream field set to the incoming stream the OPEN_REQEUEST message came in on.

When a OPEN_RESPONSE is received, the Reverse Stream value is matched against all pending OPEN_REQEUEST messages. If no match can be found, the OPEN_RESPONSE message SHOULD be ignored. If a match is found, then if the error value is 0 the bidirectional Data Channel an OPEN_ACKNOWLEDGEMENT message is sent. If the error value is non-zero, the open failed, and the originator SHOULD close down the originally-selected outgoing stream and notify the application.
The channel_type and reliability_parameters fields of the OPEN_REQEUEST message MUST be used to set up the reverse side of the Data Channel so that both directions use the same options.

section.title: Closing a Channel
section.t: Data Channels shall be closed by resetting the outgoing stream If an incoming stream is reset by the peer, an corresponding outgoing stream reset SHOULD be issued. If both streams of a channel are reset, the channel is closed.

section.title: Sending and Receiving Data
section.t: Data shall be sent using PPID's other than the Data Channel Control PPID. These PPID's should be registered with IANA via (TBD). The meaning of these data PPIDs and the format of the data shall be specific to the usage of this protocol, and typically shall be provided to the higher layers to allow proper decoding of the data.
For WebRTC, data PPID's for DOMStrings and binary data blobs shall be created.
All data sent on a Data Channel in both directions MUST be sent over the underlying Stream using the reliability defined when the Data Channel was opened.
It is recommended that message size be kept within certain bounds (TBD).
